case_title: Sardar MUHAMMAD RASHID KHAN vs AZAD JAMMU AND KASHMIR COUNCIL through Secretary, AJ&K Council Secretariat, Islamabad and 4 others
court: Azad Jammu and Kashmir Service Tribunal
respondant: AZAD JAMMU AND KASHMIR COUNCIL through Secretary, AJ&K Council Secretariat, Islamabad
complaint_summary: The appellant claimed he served AJ&K Inland Revenue for 39 years and sought anti-dated promotion to BS-17 and BS-18 before retirement. His applications were not responded to, leading to this appeal.
investigation_summary: No investigation was conducted as the case pertained to administrative promotion matters.
judgment_summary: The appeal was dismissed as it was deemed not maintainable. The Service Tribunal ruled that promotion is not a vested right and cannot be claimed retrospectively. The appellant failed to challenge any departmental order, making his claim ambiguous and legally invalid.
legal_arguments: Promotion is not a vested right and cannot be claimed retrospectively.
Section 4 of the Service Tribunals Act, 1973 requires a departmental order to be challenged for an appeal to be maintainable.
The Tribunal cannot issue directions; it can only confirm, set aside, vary, or modify orders appealed against.
key_issues: Whether promotion can be claimed as a vested right.
Whether the Service Tribunal has jurisdiction to issue directions.
Maintainability of appeal without challenging a departmental order.

maxims.Promotion is not a vested right: A person cannot claim promotion as a right or demand retrospective promotion.

legal_terms.Vested Right: A right that is secured or guaranteed and cannot be taken away.

words_and_phrases.Maintainability: The legal validity or admissibility of a case or appeal.
words_and_phrases.Departmental Order: An official decision or directive issued by a government department.

summary_vector_notes: The appellant sought retrospective promotion after retirement, which was denied as promotion is not a vested right. No departmental order was challenged, making the appeal legally invalid. The Tribunal dismissed the case, citing relevant legal precedents and statutory provisions.
